Condition Notes: Walks through the basics files controlling Collector

Condition Description: All study; The most simple case
Condition Notes: Most simple example of using Collector to show stimuli in predefined order
Showing how `Trial Type` influences presentation of the stimuli

Notice how shuffling stimuli will randomize which 'Item' corresponds to a particular stimuli but the shuffling only happens once so if I call [2,3,4] as `Study` then [2,3,4] as `Test` I will see the same ordering of stimuli [2,3,4] twice in a row

By shuffling procedure [2,3,4] for `Study` and `Test` independently I ensure there are 3 items studied followed by testing each of the 3 items.  The order of the items shown during study and test are independently shuffled without any constraints

Condition Description: Using `Shuffle` column to give stimuli structure
Condition Notes: When stimuli are shuffled by type (i.e., high and low associates) I can "sample" from each pool.  Thinking of shuffling in this way will be useful for many different experimental applications.

Condition Description: Shuffling applied to Stimuli and Procedure files
Condition Notes: Combining structured Stimuli shuffle + Procedure shuffle I've created a condition in which I study 1 high associate 3 times and 1 low associate 3 times.  Followng the randomized study phase I test each of the 2 studied items.  Choice of specific high and low associate items is randomly assigned for each participant and the ordering of items within the study and test phase are also randomized per participant.

Timing is very flexible and the `Timing` column can be `User`, `Computer`, or set to the specific number of seconds desired for the trial.  `MinTime` sets the minimum number of seconds before a trial can be submitted.  When `MinTime` is set for a trial that is `Computer` or specific # then the computer timing is treated as a maximum time.
